document_data.Personality: She was an enigma, never telling the truth when falsehood would do. Everything she did and said was shrouded in layers of illusion and lies.
document_data.Divine Realm: Leira maintained a [[divine realm]] called the Courts of Illusion on the chaotic plane of [[Limbo]]. After her apparent demise, her body was thought to be adrift on the [[Astral Plane]], like those of other dead powers.

Orders.[[Mistcaller]]s: : Specialty priests of Leira with limited powers of illusion, the Mistcallers were the clerical order most commonly associated with the church, though no one could be sure how many there were.
Orders.[[Mistwalker]]s: : A sect of the church first appearing after the [[Time of Troubles]], the [[Mistcaller]]s continued to display the ability to cast divine magic, but were purposefully ambiguous about the "alleged" death of their goddess and whether their magic was granted by a living Leira or by Cyric.

document_data.Relationships: Leira's allies were [[Mask]], who betrayed her, and [[Azuth]]. Though she had no enemies,
document_data.History:
Months after the [[Time of Troubles|Avatar Crisis]], Leira was slain by the new deity of death, [[Cyric]], wielding the sword ''[[Godsbane]]'', which was in fact an avatar of Mask. Her portfolios were subsequently absorbed by the mad god.

Upon her death, her godly power erupted in a blast that reached her places of worship all across [[Faerûn]]. Motes of her divinity coalesced into incorporeal beings known as [[Glamer (outsider)|glamers]].{{Cite dragon/299/The Dragon's Bestiary}}

Some still believed Leira was alive and that she had used her death as a grand illusion, but the general consensus was that she was a dead power.

By the late 15{{th}} century [[DR]], it became known that Leira was in fact alive and delighted in the confusion created by rumors of her demise and return. At this time, the faithful of Cyric also considered her to be his daughter.
